items.title: The Distributive Law
items.content_latex: The perimeter of a rectangle can be found by either adding all four side lengths, or doubling the sum of length and width. For example, the perimeter of the rectangle alongside is $7 + 3 + 7 + 3 = 20$ cm or $2 \times (7 + 3) = 20$ cm. If we apply these methods to a rectangle with sides in terms of a variable or variables we discover a useful algebraic result.

items.title: The product (a+b)(c+d)
items.content_latex: The expression $(a + b)(c + d)$ can be expanded by using the distributive law three times.
items.formula_latex: $(a + b)(c + d) = (a + b)c + (a + b)d = c(a + b) + d(a + b) = ac + bc + ad + bd$

questions.label: a
questions.answer_latex: $= (x + y)p + (x + y)q = p(x + y) + q(x + y) = px + py + qx + qy$

items.title: Perfect Squares
items.content_latex: Perfect squares have form $(a + b)^2$, and because we see them often in algebraic expressions we use a rule for writing down their expansions. This rule is easily established by repeated use of the distributive law. $(a+b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2$ can be demonstrated using areas.
items.explanation: The following is a useful way of remembering the perfect square rules: $(a+b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2$ where $a^2$ is the square of first term, $2ab$ is twice the product of the 2 terms, and $b^2$ is the square of second term.

items.title: Difference of Two Squares
items.content_latex: An expression of the form $(a + b)(a - b)$ is called a difference of two squares. Expanding this expression using the FOIL rule: $(a + b)(a - b) = a^2 + a(-b) + ba - b^2 = a^2 - ab + ab - b^2 = a^2 - b^2$

questions.label: a
questions.problem_latex: Show that $(n + \frac{1}{2})^2 = n^2 + n + \frac{1}{4}$ using the perfect square expansion rule.

questions.label: b
questions.problem_latex: Hence, find the value of $(2\frac{1}{2})^2$. Hint: Let $n = 2$.
